posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
Hi CD , I’m excited to announce the release of two PCB designs.

CAN Terminator This board allows for a drop in CAN termination point for the end of your loop. It comes in two variants, one with a Molex connector, and one with a Wago lever terminal. image 624×655 22.2 KB image 665×716 27.3 KB

image 624×655 22.2 KB

image 624×655 22.2 KB

image 665×716 27.3 KB

image 665×716 27.3 KB

CANvertible The CANvertible PCB allows teams to switch on and off termination at any point in the CAN loop. With a passthrough and terminator option, this is perfect for any robot with motors that stick out of the frame perimeter. Gone are the days of rushing to rewire your CAN loop when your intake breaks between matches. With this board, you can be up and running again at the flick of a switch! This also comes in Molex and Wago lever terminal variants. image 788×476 29.5 KB image 831×614 33 KB

image 788×476 29.5 KB

image 788×476 29.5 KB

image 831×614 33 KB

image 831×614 33 KB

Both boards feature a through-hole resistor for easy repairs, and zip-tie holes for mounting. In the coming weeks, I’ll be making a 3D-printed case for both of them, so stay on the lookout. Both the design files and gerbers are up on my GitHub , so feel free to modify them as you see fit.

I’m also thinking of doing a limited run (hopefully before build season) in a group buy style of these boards, but I’m not sure how to best handle shipping/distribution without it being too costly for either myself or you all. If any of y’all have experience with this, please let me know.

Thanks for reading, Matthew

link_counts.title: GitHub - superdude311/CAN-Devices: 2 CAN related PCBs for the FRC space

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
Great work - thank you so much!

For stuff and giggles I uploaded the WAGO termination kicad to DigiKey and tweaked options to enable their “DigiKey Red” pricing. At qty 10 it priced the PCBs at $1.48/ea with a 10 business-day lead time. I added the WAGO connectors (p/n 2946-233-502-ND) but struggled to find a 120Ohm resistor that fit the exact spec in the kicad, but settled on this p/n 120QBK-ND which matched your length but was a touch thinner.

All told, shipped and with tax it was $38.44 for qty 10.

Something like this, especially if DigiKey offers a voucher in the Virtual KoP again this year should put these designs well with reach of nearly every team (or small group of teams).

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: Hmmmm,  how about adding an electronic relay to every board and Java code to search and destroy the “bad” CAN node?

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: I’d double check whether the voucher applies for custom PCBs.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: Working on something like this, but I’ve got some exams coming up so it might take time. The easiest way I’ve thought of doing it would be to search for CAN faults and then send a digital output from the rio to the device to shut it down. Relays are a little bulky, so I was trying to use MOSFETs but I’m still working out some of the kinks

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: Thanks for doing this! I’ve been looking at PCBWay for my pricing but totally forgot that DigiKey gives out that voucher, I’ll definitely take a look at them too

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: Star network topology should help you, probably easier than dealing with automatically disconnecting a lost termination or network segment. some people talked about it here

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: As CAN bus speeds get higher, adherence to a bus topology is important. Star topologies tend to have long “drops” or branches from the hub, which can introduce further signal integrity issues.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
Agreed. The most I would consider a star-like topology these days is sitting on a swerve module grabbing the 2 motor controllers and an encoder in their short legs.

I can’t cite a source but I recall reading that “proper” topology matters more in CAN -FD buses than CAN2.0 busses.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
The higher the frequency, the more important the wiring details get CAN is a transmission line, and those star branches have to be electrically “short” to avoid ringing around in them.

I totally agree. A swerve star is a good trick, but wider ranging it gets dangerous.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
superdude311:

Gone are the days of rushing to rewire your CAN loop when your intake breaks between matches.

Why not use a brushed motor for this and leave the controller within your frame perimeter?

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
No reason not to! However, lots of teams don’t use brushless motors anymore on principle (specifically principles I tend to disagree with), so I figured this would work for the teams who only use brushless motors. Personally, I think it depends on the specific use case whether you need brushless motors on an intake, or if you can put them at the base of your pivot inside your frame.

BTW, everyone should look out, I’ve got some more good news coming about this in a couple of months. Stay tuned

posts.name: Will Marshall
posts.cooked:
Neato!

First off - your GitHub repository isn’t public so I can’t see it

I designed and assembled something similar for 2399 this year.

(Yet Another) Single-SKU Parts Release Technical

Some lessons learned:

We had issues with shock loads (and during assembly) breaking the dip switch pads off the rest of the board. We mitigated this by replacing the switch with a jumper wire for our intended terminator and didn’t use any others on the network. At Ohio State champs we had an unrelated guillotining PXL_20250510_155935819 1920×2550 326 KB

PXL_20250510_155935819 1920×2550 326 KB

PXL_20250510_155935819 1920×2550 326 KB

and replaced the board with one where I’d potted the switch in hot glue in the hopes of distributing loads better. We’ll see how that holds up.

You might also want to use a proper copper fill + thermal relief - just helps to anchor the connection a little better. I didn’t manage to push an iteration of my boards with this, but definitely suffered tearing out pads during assembly because it’s absence. It’s possible the through-hole setup you have will be sufficient to mitigate this.

I’ll see if I can dig up our final BOM cost for a dozen boards.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
wmarshall11:

First off - your GitHub repository isn’t public so I can’t see it

Looks like I accidentally privated it a while ago, when I went through and privated a bunch of things from school. D’oh. I’ll set it back to public. Every once in a while I go through and private a bunch of repos, and I guess I forgot that this was supposed to be an open project.

posts.name: Will Marshall
posts.cooked: and I missed that this was a 2024 post. Very nice work

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Nice. We struggled with CAN reliability in the past and dramatically reduced that in 2025 with some PCBs with latching connectors.

One thing I’d recommend is “don’t have two completely different PCBs both called CANvertible v1”.

(Call them differently enough that if you sent a team member to fetch one by part name/number alone, that they’d always bring the correct part.)

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Coming from the oilfield where we beat our downhole tool circuit boards within an inch of their lives Seriously, we have shock machines that literally hammer the entire tool on an impact pad over and over…

Yes, through hole parts are MUCH more shock resistant.  Lighter/smaller/shorter parts are more shock resistant.  Glue or encapsulation will be tricky to use with a switch; pretty easy to glue it in place…  There are some switches sealed for wave soldering that might be decent and easy enough to glue around.  Things with more legs are also more shock resistant, so you might find that the dip switch array was tougher than the single switch.  Or a SPDT switch is a little better vs SPST.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked:
sokoloff:

One thing I’d recommend is “don’t have two completely different PCBs both called CANvertible v1”.

This is what happens when you copy the main parts of a design from one to the other… To be frank, I have no idea why I called it the V1. Not like I really had huge ideas for a V2…

Weldingrod1:

Yes, through hole parts are MUCH more shock resistant. Lighter/smaller/shorter parts are more shock resistant.

Good to know my intuition checks out. Only thing I’m worried about are the wire to board connectors. Hopefully they don’t shear off.
